parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate or party.  It promotes a website that helps voters find compatible parties, but doesn't endorse any particular candidate.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message is clearly intended for a wide audience, not just a specific individual or small group.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. While the post relates to the parliamentary elections by offering a tool to help voters choose, its primary objective is not to influence the vote for a specific candidate or party. The aim is to encourage informed voting through the use of a compatibility test.  It does not advocate for or against any particular candidate.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>True. The post can be considered a form of public service announcement or citizen journalism, aiming to educate and inform voters about the electoral process. It provides a tool to help voters make informed decisions, rather than directly influencing their choices.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Not applicable. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; it presents a tool for voter engagement.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>9108703862515803</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post promotes a website (eucucinevotez.eu) designed to help voters find politically compatible parties.  While the post relates to the parliamentary elections, it does not advocate for or against any specific candidate or party. The objective is to encourage informed voting, not to influence the outcome in favor of a particular candidate. The content is educational and informative, similar to a public service announcement.  There is no direct call to vote for or against anyone.  The post does not violate Article 36 (7) a, b, c, or d because it doesn't directly refer to a candidate, it's not used during a prohibited period, it doesn't have an electoral objective in the sense of promoting a specific candidate, and it remains within the boundaries of journalistic information.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>DifinePR</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
